answer:
<p>It makes no sense to return values from a callback. Instead, do the "foo()" work you want to do <strong>inside</strong> your callback.</p>

<p>Asynchronous callbacks are invoked by the browser or by some framework like the Google geocoding library when events happen.  There's no place for returned values to go. A callback function <em>can</em> return a value, in other words, but the code that calls the function won't pay attention to the return value.</p>
data.title: How to return value from an asynchronous callback function? [duplicate]
